summary: Boeing's (BA) second quarter jet deliveries marked the company's highest quarterly deliveries number since 2023. headline: Boeing Second-Quarter Deliveries Hit Highest Level Since 2023
summary: Boeing's commercial plane deliveries for the second quarter hit the highest quarterly level since 2023, a promising sign for CEO Kelly Ortberg's efforts to turn around the beleaguered plane maker.  The aerospace giant said it delivered 60 planes to customers in June, bringing second-quarter deliveries to 150, the highest since a door plug blew out on an Alaska Airlines flight and drew new scrutiny on the company’s manufacturing operations.  Boeing has struggled to return to normal production levels for years, challenged by the fallout from a pair of MAX jet crashes in 2018 and 2019, the Covid-19 pandemic and other issues.

raw.headline: Boeing Second-Quarter Deliveries Hit Highest Level Since 2023
raw.summary: Boeing's commercial plane deliveries for the second quarter hit the highest quarterly level since 2023, a promising sign for CEO Kelly Ortberg's efforts to turn around the beleaguered plane maker.  The aerospace giant said it delivered 60 planes to customers in June, bringing second-quarter deliveries to 150, the highest since a door plug blew out on an Alaska Airlines flight and drew new scrutiny on the company’s manufacturing operations.  Boeing has struggled to return to normal production levels for years, challenged by the fallout from a pair of MAX jet crashes in 2018 and 2019, the Covid-19 pandemic and other issues.

headline: Boeing delivers 60 jets in June, including 8 to China, as it resumes deliveries
summary: SEATTLE (Reuters) -Boeing said Tuesday that it delivered 60 airplanes in June, a 27% increase compared to a year earlier, including eight to Chinese customers for the first time since a trade spat between the countries ended.  Beijing had banned delivery of Boeing aircraft in April as a tariff dispute escalated between the world's two biggest economies, but in May, it removed that ban, as the two countries agreed to temporarily cut steep tariffs.  Aircraft deliveries are closely tracked by Wall Street because planemakers collect much of their payment when they hand over jets to customers.

raw.headline: Boeing delivers 60 jets in June, including 8 to China, as it resumes deliveries
raw.summary: SEATTLE (Reuters) -Boeing said Tuesday that it delivered 60 airplanes in June, a 27% increase compared to a year earlier, including eight to Chinese customers for the first time since a trade spat between the countries ended.  Beijing had banned delivery of Boeing aircraft in April as a tariff dispute escalated between the world's two biggest economies, but in May, it removed that ban, as the two countries agreed to temporarily cut steep tariffs.  Aircraft deliveries are closely tracked by Wall Street because planemakers collect much of their payment when they hand over jets to customers.

headline: Boeing Stock Dips as Wait Drags On for Fatal 787 Air India Crash Update. What We Know.
summary: Boeing  stock dropped slightly early Tuesday as investors wait for details from flight data recorders on board Air India flight 171, which crashed on June 12, less than a minute after taking off from an airport in Ahmedabad.  One thing that might help Tuesday is a small price-target increase from Deutsche Bank analyst Scott Deuschle.  Boeing stock traded as low as $195.28 in the days after the crash but has since recovered, trading around a 52-week high.

raw.headline: Boeing Stock Dips as Wait Drags On for Fatal 787 Air India Crash Update. What We Know.
raw.summary: Boeing  stock dropped slightly early Tuesday as investors wait for details from flight data recorders on board Air India flight 171, which crashed on June 12, less than a minute after taking off from an airport in Ahmedabad.  One thing that might help Tuesday is a small price-target increase from Deutsche Bank analyst Scott Deuschle.  Boeing stock traded as low as $195.28 in the days after the crash but has since recovered, trading around a 52-week high.

headline: Ryanair sees strong summer bookings, CEO says heatwave not stopping travel
summary: STORY: Ryanair has seen strong bookings and rising prices for its summer season.And there are no signs customers have delayed holidays due to a recent heatwave.That was the word from airline CEO Michael O'Leary on Tuesday (July 8).He reaffirmed a May forecast that the Irish airline would recover most, but not all, of the 7% fall in average fares reported last year.That was when consumers struggled with high interest rates.O'Leary said August looks strong for a number of destinations, including Italy, Greece and Spain.He further said he was hopeful commercial aircraft will be exempt from U.S. and EU tariffs, but admitted "nobody is really sure".Ryanair sources almost all of its aircraft from U.S. planemaker Boeing.

raw.headline: Ryanair sees strong summer bookings, CEO says heatwave not stopping travel

headline: China Airlines and The New Terminal One Announce Strategic Partnership, Transforming Customer Experience in New York City
summary: China Airlines (CAL), a Taiwan-based carrier, will begin operations at The New Terminal One at New York John F. Kennedy International Airport in 2026, launching an elevated travel experience for its valued customers. The long-term partnership between China Airlines and the New Terminal One will support the carrier's ambition to expand its network in North America, transforming the customer experience at one of the airline's top international gateways.
